newsitem.title: USA: Mason-Dixon files suit vs investor group.
newsitem.headline: Mason-Dixon files suit vs investor group.

text.p: Mason-Dixon Bancshares Inc said on Monday it filed suit in U.S. district court against a group of 17 investors led by a former employee.

The suit sought declaratory and injunctive relief under U.S. federal securities laws and under Maryland banking laws, the company said. The group, which had a 5.1 percent ownership stake in Mason-Dixon, said on November 22 the company should explore oppportunities for a merger or consolidation.
In a 13D filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said the company's earnings were below the industry average.

The investors, led by Barbara Floyd, president of Anthony Investments and a former Mason-Dixon employee, filed a 13D last month with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to report the group had beneficial ownership of 5.1 percent of Mason's voting stock, the company said.
Mason-Dixon said Alvie Spencer Jr., a former company director who was removed from his post last year, was also part of the group.

Mason-Dixon said the company has consistently outperformed its national peer group in 1992, 1993 and 1994 and earnings have only been affected recently as a result of a July 1995 acquisition of the Bank of Maryland.

It also said the 13D contained an agreement between Anthony Investments and the group, for Floyd's company to receive a fee upon sale of Mason-Dixon, or if the company's share price rose above $17.50 per share.
Mason-Dixon is the parent company of Carroll County Bank and Trust and Bank of Maryland.
